docs.lead_paragraph: A FEW months after Bill and Pamela Matassoni bought and began restoring Philip Johnson's 1956 Boissonas house in New Canaan, Bill got a call from the architect himself -- ''Do you need help?'' -- and a visit the next Saturday. With the Matassonis in tow, Mr. Johnson walked through the brick and glass villa and started describing the complex floor plan in scholarly architectural terms. ''You realize I was breaking up the Miesian cube when I built this,'' he explained. The Matassonis exchanged puzzled glances, and Mr. Matassoni replied, ''Oh, yeah, we knew that.'' The Boissonas house was one of six Modernist homes Mr. Johnson designed in New Canaan, and his favorite aside from his own, the Glass House.
docs.abstract: Article on architect Philip Johnson, who has died at age 98, and influence he had on New Canaan, Conn, where he designed six Modernist houses; Johnson's two favorite houses, the Glass House in which he lived and Boissonas, now owned by Bill and Pamela Matassoni, described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the BMW's and Mercedeses pulled into the Sunset Harbour condominium complex here, the parking valets rushed over to help, ignoring the 25 union supporters who stood across the street, angrily thumping plastic buckets and shouting, ''Union!'' Several well-tanned women, one in an imitation leopard coat, sauntered into the 26-story tower, largely oblivious to the demonstrators, who, to their dismay, failed to attract any television news crews.

headline.main: Labor Tries Organizing in the Union-Wary South

docs.abstract: Service Employees International Union is undertaking one of largest private-sector organizing drives in South in decades, seeking to represent 7,000 condominium workers mostly in Miami area; Pres Andrew Stern's aides say that unions need to expand in South if they are serious about reversing their decline; secondary motive is to create conditions in which labor-friendly candidates can be elected in region; challenge is daunting, as many employers are fiercely anti-union; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The Service Employees International Union is seeking to represent 7,000 condominium workers, mostly immigrants, in the Miami area.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a pot of split-pea soup simmered on the stove recently, Jennifer Christensen and her mother, Josephine, planned the feast they would whip up to celebrate Jennifer's impending 22nd birthday: stuffed shells, chicken cutlets, eggplant parmesan, cannoli cake. They are expecting quite a gathering at their house here: Jennifer's aunt and sister-in-law from Yorktown, her two uncles, her best friend and perhaps a cousin.

headline.main: As Obesity Runs in Families, So Does Surgery to Combat It

docs.abstract: Article on rise in number of families in Westchester County, NY, whose members are undergoing stomach-reduction, or bariatric, surgery; number of people undergoing bariatric surgery has risen from 63,100 nationwide three years ago to estimated 170,000 today, but rise is number of cases is dramatically higher in Westchester; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Something that seems to have been lost or ignored in the current debate about Social Security is that the program was founded on the insurance principle of shared risk (Roger Lowenstein, Jan. 16). We accept this without question when we pay for life insurance, homeowner's coverage and health insurance. We do not build up a reserve in a personal account but rather pay for protection over a certain period of time. Why shouldn't we be satisfied with the same approach for our pensions? Social Security taxes are nothing more than a form of deferred savings, and many people will be returned every cent they ever paid in and more. But as with other forms of insurance, though we may never collect a cent, we have peace of mind because of the protection we have enjoyed. Social Security operates very efficiently with an exceedingly low administrative cost. Further, there are no individual fees to be paid for account management. Admittedly, the return on Social Security funds is not as high as on stocks or bonds, but there is far less risk involved, another financial principle that should be emphasized: the higher the rate of return, the greater the financial risk. Jim Harnden West Bloomfield, Mich.
docs.abstract: letter comments on Roger Lowenstein's Jan 16 article on debate over Social Security
docs.snippet: Something that seems to have been lost or ignored in the current debate about Social Security is that the program was founded on the insurance principle of shared risk (Roger Lowenstein, Jan. 16). We accept this without question when we pay for life...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Columbia University opened a private elementary school on 110th Street and Broadway in the fall of 2003, it was touted as the embodiment of an almost utopian vision: five floors of gleaming high-tech classrooms presided over by gifted, well-paid teachers serving a student body composed equally of children of Columbia employees and children from the Morningside Heights community. But just one year after angering the community by admitting four children outside of the lottery that had been set up to choose local youngsters, Columbia has infuriated members of its own faculty by turning away dozens of children whose parents had been led to believe that their acceptance was assured.

headline.main: At Columbia's Grade School, a Blot on a Bold Experiment

docs.abstract: Private elementary school opened by Columbia University in 2003 to help retain faculty has become subject of angry recrimination among parents whose children have been left out despite promises of automatic admission; photo; university, which also admits some neighborhood children, did not anticipate demand; names task force to develop new policy (M)
docs.snippet: Columbia University's private elementary school has infuriated faculty members by turning away dozens of children whose parents had been led to believe that their acceptance was assured.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE drive to create a life sciences hub at i.park Lake Success is moving forward. Patrick Duggan, Nassau's deputy county executive for economic development, said last Monday $1.7 million was in sight to finance the construction of a 10,000-square-foot training center here. The center will include classrooms, a computer lab and a 140-seat auditorium and will be equipped with laboratory equipment like a centrifuge, microscopes and high-tech audiovisual equipment. It will serve as place where present and potential employees can be trained to work in the specialized life sciences industry: in medical laboratories, for example, and at hospitals and companies that make medical equipment.

headline.main: I.park Training Center Closer to Reality

docs.abstract: Deputy County Executive Patrick Duggan says Nassau County has submitted $1.5 million loan application to Department of Housing and Urban Development to help finance construction of 10,000-square-foot life sciences training center at i.park Lake Success; says remaining $200,000 will come from fund-raising and grant money; center will include classrooms, computer lab and auditorium equipped with laboratory equipment; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE drive to create a life sciences hub at i.park Lake Success is moving forward. Patrick Duggan, Nassau's deputy county executive for economic development, said last Monday $1.7 million was in sight to finance the construction of a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Carl M. Steubing, a decorated Battle of the Bulge veteran whose experience of war made him a pacifist but also instilled in him a zest for living life at full tilt, took his diagnosis of gastroesophageal cancer in 2001 as a challenge. With a thatch of white hair and a rich baritone voice, Mr. Steubing, at 78, was not ready to succumb to illness. A retired music educator and wedding photographer, he remained active as a church choir director, expert cook, painter, golfer and fisherman. He was married to a woman 24 years his junior, and they had seven children and three grandchildren between them.

headline.main: IN HARM'S WAY: Research, Fraud and the V.A.; Abuses Endangered Veterans In Cancer Drug Experiments

docs.abstract: Cancer research program at Stratton Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Albany, NY, exemplifies systematic weaknesses in human research protections program cited in internal memorandum of Veterans Affairs Dept in 2003, especially in industry-funded studies, which account for about 80 percent of department's human research; internal whistleblowers at Stratton faced reprisals; Food and Drug Administration and General Accounting Office investigative teams found pattern of non-compliance with regulations; external non-profit National Committee for Quality Assurance began ongoing accreditation process for program in 2001, and has accredited just under one third of 118 research centers; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Scores of patients at the V.A. hospital inAlbany were put at risk, and employees say bigger concerns were dismissed by officials.

docs.lead_paragraph: A large advocacy group for American retirees said on Friday that it had won a court order barring the government from allowing companies to drop older retirees from health care coverage while retaining coverage for younger retirees. The court ruling, issued Friday, temporarily blocks the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission from issuing a new rule that would allow companies, battling rising health care costs, to drop health insurance coverage when their retirees turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare coverage.

headline.main: Court Blocks Rule Change on Retiree Health Care

docs.abstract: AARP wins court order temporarily barring Equal Employment Opportunity Commission from issuing new rule that would allow companies to drop health insurance coverage when their retirees turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare; hearing has been set for March 31 to hear arguments on permanently banning rule (M)
docs.snippet: A large advocacy group for American retirees said on Friday that it had won a court order barring the government from allowing companies to drop older retirees from health care coverage while retaining coverage for younger retirees.
